section.title: Overview
section.para: The dialog module provides dialog awareness to the &kamailio; proxy. Its functionality is to keep track of the current dialogs, to offer information about them (like how many dialogs are active) or to manage them. The module exports several functions that could be used directly from scripts.

section.title: How it works
section.para: To create the dialog associated to an initial request, the flag dlg_flag () must be set before creating the corresponding transaction.

The dialog is automatically destroyed when a BYE is received. In case of no BYE, the dialog lifetime is controlled via the default timeout (see default_timeout - ) and custom timeout (see timeout_avp - ). The dialog timeout is reset each time a sequential request passes.

section.title: Dialog profiling
section.para: Dialog profiling is a mechanism that helps in classifying, sorting and keeping trace of certain types of dialogs, using whatever properties of the dialog (like caller, destination, type of calls, etc). Dialogs can be dynamically added in different (and several) profile tables - logically, each profile table can have a special meaning (like dialogs outside the domain, dialogs terminated to PSTN, etc).
A dialog can be added to multiple profiles in the same time.
Profiles are visible (at the moment) in the request route (for initial and sequential requests) and in the branch, failure and reply routes of the original request.

section.title: &kamailio; Modules
section.para:
The following modules must be loaded before this module:
TM - Transaction module
RR - Record-Route module

section.title: External Libraries or Applications
section.para:
The following libraries or applications must be installed before running &kamailio; with this module loaded:
None.

section.title: enable_stats (integer)
section.para: If the statistics support should be enabled or not. Via statistic variables, the module provide information about the dialog processing. Set it to zero to disable or to non-zero to enable it.

section.title: hash_size (integer)
section.para: The size of the hash table internally used to keep the dialogs. A larger table is much faster but consumes more memory. The hash size must be a power of two number.

IMPORTANT: If dialogs' information should be stored in a database, a constant hash_size should be used, otherwise the restoring process will not take place. If you really want to modify the hash_size you must delete all table's rows before restarting the server.

section.title: rr_param (string)
section.para: Name of the Record-Route parameter to be added with the dialog cookie. It is used for the fast dialog matching of sequential requests.

section.title: dlg_flag (integer)
section.para: Flag to be used for marking if a dialog should be constructed for the current request (this make sense only for initial requests).

section.title: timeout_avp (string)
default_timeout (integer)
section.para: The default dialog timeout (in seconds) if no custom one is set.

section.title: dlg_extra_hdrs (string)
section.para: A string containing the extra headers (full format, with EOH) to be added in the requests generated by the module (like BYEs).

section.title: dlg_match_mode (integer)
section.para: How the sequential requests should be matched against the known dialogs. The modes are a combination between matching based on a cookie (DID) stored as cookie in Record-Route header and the matching based on SIP elements (as in RFC3261).
The supported modes are:

listitem.para: 0 - DID_ONLY - the match is done exclusively based on DID;
2 - DID_NONE - the match is done exclusively based on SIP elements; no DID information is added in RR.

section.title: detect_spirals (integer)
section.para: Whether spirals (i.e., messages routed through the proxy multiple times) should be detected or not.

If set to 0, spirals will not be detected and result in the generation of a new, possibly dangling dialog structure per occurring spiral. If set to 1, spirals are detected and internally mapped to existing dialog structures.
Default value is 1.

section.title: db_url (string)
section.para: If you want to store the information about the dialogs in a database a database url must be specified.

section.title: db_mode (integer)
section.para: Describe how to push into the DB the dialogs' information from memory.
The supported modes are:

listitem.para: 0 - NO_DB - the memory content is not flushed into DB;
1 - REALTIME - any dialog information changes will be reflected into the database immediatly.
2 - DELAYED - the dialog information changes will be flushed into DB periodically, based on a timer routine.
3 - SHUTDOWN - the dialog information will be flushed into DB only at shutdown - no runtime updates.

section.title: db_update_period (integer)
section.para: The interval (seconds) at which to update dialogs' information if you chose to store the dialogs' info at a given interval. A too short interval will generate intensive database operations, a too large one will not notice short dialogs.

section.title: db_fetch_rows (integer)
section.para: The number of the rows to be fetched at once from database when loading the dialog records at startup from the database. This value can be used to tune the load time at startup. For 1MB of private memory (default) it should be below 400. The database driver must support fetch_result() capability. A value of 0 means the functionality is disabled.

section.title: table_name (string)
section.para: If you want to store the information about the dialogs in a database a table name must be specified.

section.title: callid_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the dialogs' callid.

section.title: from_uri_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the caller's sip address.

section.title: from_tag_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the From tag from the INVITE request.

section.title: to_uri_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the callee's sip address.

section.title: to_tag_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the To tag from the 200 OK response to the INVITE request, if present.

section.title: caller_cseq_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the cseq from caller side.

section.title: callee_cseq_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the cseq from callee side.

section.title: caller_route_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the route records from caller side (proxy to caller).

section.title: callee_route_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the route records from callee side (proxy to callee).

section.title: caller_contact_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the caller's contact uri.

section.title: callee_contact_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the callee's contact uri.

section.title: caller_sock_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the information about the local interface receiving the traffic from caller.

section.title: callee_sock_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store information about the local interface receiving the traffic from callee.

section.title: h_id_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the dialogs' hash id information.

section.title: h_entry_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the dialogs' hash entry information.

section.title: state_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the dialogs' state information.

section.title: start_time_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the dialogs' start time information.

section.title: timeout_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the dialogs' timeout.

section.title: sflags_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the script flags.

section.title: toroute_column (string)
section.para: The column name in the database to store the index of the route to be executed at timeout.

section.title: profiles_with_value (string)
section.para: List of names for profiles with values.

section.title: profiles_no_value (string)
section.para: List of names for profiles without values.

section.title: bridge_controller (string)
section.para: SIP address to be used in From header when initiating a call bridge.

Inserts the current dialog into a profile. Note that if the profile does not supports values, this will be silently discarded. Also, there is no check for inserting the same dialog in the same profile for multiple times.
Meaning of the parameters is as follows:

listitem.para: profile - name of the profile to be added to;
value (optional) - string value to define the belonging of the dialog to the profile - note that the profile must support values. Pseudo-variables are supported.

section.para: This function can be used from REQUEST_ROUTE, BRANCH_ROUTE, REPLY_ROUTE and FAILURE_ROUTE.
Removes the current dialog from a profile.
Meaning of the parameters is as follows:

listitem.para: profile - name of the profile to be removed from;
value (optional) - string value to define the belonging of the dialog to the profile - note that the profile must support values. Pseudo-variables are supported.

section.para: This function can be used from BRANCH_ROUTE, REPLY_ROUTE and FAILURE_ROUTE.

Checks if the current dialog belongs to a profile. If the profile supports values, the check can be reinforced to take into account a specific value - if the dialog was inserted into the profile for a specific value. If no value is passed, only the simply belonging of the dialog to the profile is checked. Note that if the profile does not supports values, this will be silently discarded.
Meaning of the parameters is as follows:

listitem.para: profile - name of the profile to be checked against;
value (optional) - string value to further restrict the check. Pseudo-variables are supported.

section.para: This function can be used from REQUEST_ROUTE, BRANCH_ROUTE, REPLY_ROUTE and FAILURE_ROUTE.

example.title: is_in_profile usage

section.para: Returns the number of dialogs belonging to a profile. If the profile supports values, the check can be reinforced to take into account a specific value - how many dialogs were inserted into the profile with a specific value. If no value is passed, only simply belonging of the dialog to the profile is checked. Note that if the profile does not supports values, this will be silently discarded.
Meaning of the parameters is as follows:

listitem.para: profile - name of the profile to get the size for;
value (optional) - string value to further restrict the check. Pseudo-variables are supported;
size - an AVP or script variable to return the profile size in.

section.para: This function can be used from REQUEST_ROUTE, BRANCH_ROUTE, REPLY_ROUTE and FAILURE_ROUTE.

example.title: get_profile_size usage

section.para: Check if the dialog flag is set or not.
Meaning of the parameters is as follows:

listitem.para: flag - index of the flag - can be pseudo-variable.

section.para: This function can be used from BRANCH_ROUTE, REQUEST_ROUTE, ONREPLY_ROUTE and FAILURE_ROUTE.
Set the dialog flag.
Meaning of the parameters is as follows:

listitem.para: flag - index of the flag - can be pseudo-variable.

section.para: This function can be used from BRANCH_ROUTE, REQUEST_ROUTE, ONREPLY_ROUTE and FAILURE_ROUTE.
Reset the dialog flag.
Meaning of the parameters is as follows:

listitem.para: flag - index of the flag - can be pseudo-variable.

section.para: This function can be used from BRANCH_ROUTE, REQUEST_ROUTE, ONREPLY_ROUTE and FAILURE_ROUTE.
Send BYE to parties in dialog.
Meaning of the parameters is as follows:

listitem.para: side - where to send the BYE. It can be: caller, callee or both of them.

section.para: This function can be used from BRANCH_ROUTE, REQUEST_ROUTE, ONREPLY_ROUTE and FAILURE_ROUTE.
Refer the 'side' to a new SIP 'address'.
Meaning of the parameters is as follows:

listitem.para: side - which part to REFER. It can be: caller or callee.
address - SIP address to refer to.

section.para: This function can be used from BRANCH_ROUTE, REQUEST_ROUTE, ONREPLY_ROUTE and FAILURE_ROUTE.
Process current SIP request with dialog module. It is alternative to setting dialog flag for initial INVITE and Route-parameter-callback execution for within-dialog requests.
This function can be used from REQUEST_ROUTE.
Bridge 'from' SIP address to 'to' SIP address via outbound proxy 'op'.
Meaning of the parameters is as follows:

listitem.para: from - SIP address of first side to call.
to - SIP address to refer from to.
op - outbound proxy SIP address.

section.para: This function can be used from BRANCH_ROUTE, REQUEST_ROUTE, ONREPLY_ROUTE and FAILURE_ROUTE.
Search and set current dialog based on Call-ID, From-Tag and To-Tag parameters.
Meaning of the parameters is as follows:

listitem.para: callid - SIP call-id.
ftag - SIP From tag.
ttag - SIP To tag.

section.para: This function can be used from BRANCH_ROUTE, REQUEST_ROUTE, ONREPLY_ROUTE and FAILURE_ROUTE.
Returns the number of current active dialogs (may be confirmed or not).
Returns the number of early dialogs.
Returns the total number of processed dialogs (terminated, expired or active) from the startup.
Returns the total number of expired dialogs from the startup.
Returns the number of failed dialogs.
Lists the description of a dialog or of all dialogs (calls). If only one dialogs is to be listed, the dialog identifiers are to be passed as parameter (callid and fromtag).
Name: dlg_list
Parameters:

listitem.para: callid (optional) - callid if a single dialog to be listed.

from_tag (optional, but cannot be present without the callid parameter) - from tag (as per initial request) of the dialog to be listed. Note that if the from_tag is not specified, only dialogs created by a request without a from tag are matched, which will only occur with broken clients and is thus a very rare situation.

section.para: MI FIFO Command Format:
The same as the dlg_list but including in the dialog description the associated context from modules sitting on top of the dialog module.
Name: dlg_list_ctx
Parameters: see dlg_list
MI FIFO Command Format:
Terminates a confirmed dialog by sending BYE requests in both directions.
Name: dlg_end_dlg
Parameters:

listitem.para: h_entry - hash entry of the dialog in the internal dialog table
h_id - hash id of the dialog on the hash entry
extra_hdrs - (optional) string containg extra headers (full format) to be added to the BYE requests.

section.para: The values for the h_entry and h_id can be get via the dlg_list MI command.
MI FIFO Command Format:
Terminates a singe dialog, identified by a Call-ID.
Name: dlg_terminate_dlgs
Parameters:

listitem.para: callid - callid of the dialog to be terminated.

from_tag (optional, but cannot be present without the callid parameter) - from tag (as per initial request) of the dialog to be terminated. Note that if the from_tag is not specified, only dialogs created by a request without a from tag are matched, which will only occur with broken clients and is thus a very rare situation.

section.para: MI FIFO Command Format:

Returns the number of dialogs belonging to a profile. If the profile supports values, the check can be reinforced to take into account a specific value - how many dialogs were inserted into the profile with a specific value. If no value is passed, only the simply belonging of the dialog to the profile is checked. Note that if the profile does not supports values, this will be silently discarded.
Name: profile_get_size
Parameters:

listitem.para: profile - name of the profile to get the value for.
value (optional)- string value to further restrict the check;

section.para: MI FIFO Command Format:

Lists all the dialogs belonging to a profile. If the profile supports values, the check can be reinforced to take into account a specific value - list only the dialogs that were inserted into the profile with that specific value. If no value is passed, all dialogs belonging to the profile will be listed. Note that if the profile does not supports values, this will be silently discarded.
Name: profile_list_dlgs
Parameters:

listitem.para: profile - name of the profile to list the dialog for.
value (optional)- string value to further restrict the check;

section.para: MI FIFO Command Format:
Bridge two SIP addresses in a call using INVITE(hold)-REFER-BYE mechanism.
Name: dlg_bridge
Parameters:

listitem.para: from - SIP address to initiate the call
to - SIP address to refer 'from' to
op (optional) - outbound proxy SIP address

section.para: MI FIFO Command Format:
Lists the description of all dialogs (calls).
Name: dlg.list
RPC Command Format:
The same as the dlg_list but including in the dialog description the associated context from modules sitting on top of the dialog module.
Name: dlg.list_ctx
RPC Command Format:
Lists the description of one dialog. The dialog identifiers are to be passed as parameter (callid and fromtag).
Name: dlg.dlg_list
Parameters:

listitem.para: callid callid of the dialog to be listed.
from_tag from tag (as per initial request) of the dialog to be listed.

section.para: RPC Command Format:
The same as the dlg.list_ctx but including in the dialog description the associated context from modules sitting on top of the dialog module.
Name: dlg.dlg_list_ctx
Parameters: see dlg_list
RPC Command Format:
Terminates an ongoing dialog by sending BYE in both directions.
Name: dlg.end_dlg
Parameters:

listitem.para: h_entry - hash entry of the dialog in the internal dialog table
h_id - hash id of the dialog on the hash entry
extra_hdrs - (optional) string containg extra headers (full format) to be added to the BYE requests.

section.para: The values for the h_entry and h_id can be get via the dlg_list RPC command.
RPC Command Format:

Returns the number of dialogs belonging to a profile. If the profile supports values, the check can be reinforced to take into account a specific value - how many dialogs were inserted into the profile with a specific value. If no value is passed, only the simply belonging of the dialog to the profile is checked. Note that if the profile does not supports values, this will be silently discarded.
Name: dlg.profile_get_size
Parameters:

listitem.para: profile - name of the profile to get the value for.
value (optional)- string value to further restrict the check;

section.para: RPC Command Format:

Lists all the dialogs belonging to a profile. If the profile supports values, the check can be reinforced to take into account a specific value - list only the dialogs that were inserted into the profile with that specific value. If no value is passed, all dialogs belonging to the profile will be listed. Note that if the profile does not supports values, this will be silently discarded.
Name: dlg.profile_list
Parameters:

listitem.para: profile - name of the profile to list the dialog for.
value (optional)- string value to further restrict the check;

section.para: RPC Command Format:
Bridge two SIP addresses in a call using INVITE(hold)-REFER-BYE mechanism.
Name: dlg.bridge_dlg
Parameters:

listitem.para: from - SIP address to initiate the call
to - SIP address to refer 'from' to
op (optional) - outbound proxy SIP address

section.para: RPC Command Format:
Returns the number of current active dialogs (may be confirmed or not).
Returns the status of the dialog corresponding to the processed sequential request. This PV will be available only for sequential requests, after doing loose_route().
Value may be:

listitem.para: NULL - Dialog not found.
3 - Confirmed by a final reply but no ACK received yet.
4 - Confirmed by a final reply and ACK received.
5 - Dialog ended.

section.para: Returns the duration (in seconds) of the dialog corresponding to the processed sequential request. The duration is calculated from the dialog confirmation and the current moment. This PV will be available only for sequential requests, after doing loose_route().
NULL will be returned if there is no dialog for the request.
Access to dialog attributes.
Access to dialog context attributes.
